{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3157264,"name":"","username":"BigBrainAhmed","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/8797f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-04T22:04:50.343Z","cooked":"

We are trying to move the clasps for our hand with Pneumatics, but are not sure how to connect it to the wood. Thank you in advance.

Screenshot 2023-03-04 at 5.04.14 PM1920×1421 447 KB

Screenshot 2023-03-04 at 5.04.06 PM1920×1417 410 KB

This on the end of the cylinder:

image536×536 43.2 KB

And this screwed into the wood:

image536×536 40.3 KB

Then set the pin through both. That would be my typical way to connect the air cylinder to a block of wood.

If you don’t have a clevis (first picture), the threads are fine thread. We’ve sometimes made and tapped our own. The air cylinder mount in the second picture could be made also.

What size is the cylinder rod thread? 1/4"-28?

If the cylinder doesn’t pivot, you could screw a coupling nut onto the end, drill a hole in the wood and use a 1/4"-28 machine screw on the other side to fasten the coupling nut to the wood. Flat washers under the screw head and coupling nut would help prevent crushing the wood.

On another note, are you really securing a pneumatic cylinder with zip-ties? If the cylinder doesn’t pivot, I recommend a foot mounting bracket. But maybe the zip-ties accomodate some misalignment.

You might luck out and find a fine thread tee nut… I vote team clevis
A little bit of mis-alignment ability is good for pneumatics.
